title: Rylan is the best presenter on TV – no matter what the haters say
text:
Rylan Clark-Neal has hit back at the haters (Picture: BBC)

He’s on Strictly: It Takes Two, he’s brought back Supermarket Sweep, he’s a universal favourite on This Morning, and he’s even conquered the airwaves on Radio 2.

With a new Channel 4 project lined up for later in the year, telly bosses truly can’t get enough of Rylan Clark-Neal.

But why so much nastiness? Recently there has been an onslaught of media coverage about him hitting back at trolls, or about viewers complaining that he’s ‘ruining’ their favourite shows.

And judging by the sheer hysteria in the replies to the Strictly Twitter account after his first It Takes Two episode, you’d think he’d set fire to the stage and locked Zoe Ball in a sequinned dungeon.

Well I’m sorry, but if liking Rylan is wrong, then frankly I don’t want to be right.

Advertisement

Advertisement

It hasn’t always been this way, though. Initially I was far from a Rylan stan.

Flash your minds back to 7 October 2012. Almost exactly seven years ago.

It’s the first live results show of The X Factor’s ninth season. Christopher Maloney, Ella Henderson, James Arthur, Union J and Jahmene Douglas are all through to next week. Rylan is in the bottom two with Carolynne Poole.

It was tough to take him too seriously at first (Picture: ITV Picture Desk) Nicole Scherzinger, his mentor, saves him. Gary Barlow, Carolynne’s mentor, saves her – making a handful of needlessly spiteful remarks at Rylan’s expense. Tulisa votes the same way, but does so nicely.

Then it gets to Louis Walsh. Oh boy. It’s one of the most iconic results show controversies in X Factor history (Lucie Jones vs Jedward? Forget it!) as he flaps around for what feels like eight and a half years and even appears to change his mind once or twice before finally sending home Carolynne. It’s a tie. Two votes each. We’re in deadlock.

Gary’s on his feet; he’s going to pass out from the rage. Poor Carolynne just wants to be put out of her misery. The crowd are absolutely beside themselves. And finally Dermot O’Leary reveals it was Carolynne who polled the fewest votes from the viewers. Rylan stays – and becomes public enemy number one.

Like a lot of viewers at the time, I was fuming. Fuming! See, I took that show very seriously back then: Once my brother put up a wall chart for the football World Cup in the family kitchen and I incredulously asked what would happen if I put up a wall chart for The X Factor live shows. He laughed. I wasn’t joking.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Because I took it so seriously, I was never a fan of the contestants who were (arguably) there more for the sake of creating an entertaining TV show than finding a viable pop star. And though Rylan certainly wasn’t in the same ballpark as Wagner and Honey G, it also didn’t feel like he was on the cusp of international music superstardom.

But despite all the controversy, he was consistently voted for by the public. His popularity was growing. There was a self-awareness about him; the sense that he was taking his performances seriously – but he wasn’t taking himself seriously at the same time. He also realised that the best way to overcome Gary Barlow was to (lightly) rib him back; and in an otherwise very serious year (James Arthur and Christopher Maloney hardly scream ‘club night’, do they), he was the only one who brought the fun.

I, like millions of others, really warmed to him. He made it to the final five, was on Celebrity Big Brother within weeks, landed a co-hosting gig on Big Brother’s Bit On The Side, and the rest is history.

His initial forays into TV presenting weren’t perfect, and given the amount of reality stars who land those sorts of jobs on a short term basis, it was tough to take him too seriously at first.

Hosting is way harder than it looks – especially when it’s live (Picture: Ken McKay/ITV/REX)

But as time went on, it became obvious that he wasn’t going anywhere. His natural warmth and humour made him a skilled host, and slowly more projects began to stack up. Now, it seems, he is inescapable; and along the way, he’s become one of the best (and most in-demand) TV personalities in the country.

Advertisement

However, despite all the love (and make no mistake, he is very popular), not everyone is happy about his recent domination.

‘He’s annoying!’ cry some people. ‘He makes me feel sick!’ tweet others. He’s a ‘talentless waste of space trying to be the centre of attention,’ moaned one Twitter user who perhaps hasn’t had a nice cuddle in a good few years.

I don’t get it – Rylan’s a natural. If Olly Murs fronting The X Factor in 2015 taught us anything, it’s that hosting is way harder than it looks – especially when it’s live.

That the likes of Emma Willis, Ant and Dec, Ore Oduba and Phil and Holly are able to make it look easy is a testament to their skill, and Rylan is similarly effortless. He always seems in control, he has a sincerity that never boils over into forced earnestness… Heck, he has a sense of humour!

I worry that some of the pushback he gets is rooted in veiled classism and homophobia. When certain snobby people hear a strong Essex accent, they immediately think ‘annoying’; and when they see a gay man showing exuberance and passion, femme-shaming is sure to follow (remember when Jonathan Van Ness had to call out a BuzzFeed quiz for suggesting his personality ‘might not be for everyone’?). I saw one tweet saying ‘ditch the diva’ which is… well, it’s certainly telling.

Advertisement

It’s been seven years since Rylan became a household name. And – like fellow telly-contestant-turned-host Alison Hammond – he wouldn’t have stayed the course if he didn’t deserve it.

Through hard work, kindness and sheer determination, he has become one of the best people on British television.

Long may his reign continue.
